Tyler Ross

I'm a researcher who is excited to develop generative AI that is capable of solving math/physics problems and formulating new hypotheses. My background, which has spanned from quantum information theory to experimental protein engineering, has provided me with the skills to quickly adapt to new fields of research and solve scientific problems.

Email

Experience

Physics of Living Systems Fellow
MIT, Cambridge, MA
2023 - Present

My primary focus is on developing methods for generative large language models (LLMs) to analyze and design DNA sequences for forming nanostructures. I have shown that general purpose LLMs, like ChatGPT, are able to capture the physical rules that govern secondary structure formation (i.e. structures beyond the familiar double helix). Additionally, I am managing projects on motor-propelled DNA structures and self-propelled condensates.

Postdoctoral Scholar
Caltech, Pasadena, CA
2020 - 2023

I developed a theory and simulations that predict that self-propelled microscopic objects can be organized by friction patches in a similar manner to how light is modulated by lenses and prisms. I also developed an experimental system for controlling the motion of DNA structures propelled by engineered motor proteins. Both projects are advancements in creating self-contained devices for routing molecular cargo in diagnostic applications and in developing autonomous cell-sized machines.

PhD in Biology
Caltech, Pasadena, CA
2014 - 2020

For my thesis I engineered a biomolecular system that allows for the light-controlled organization of motor proteins and the filamentous tracks they walk on. This work is a step toward establishing the guiding principles for creating cell-sized machines that can be programmed to perform mechanical tasks.

Biostatistician
Yale, New Haven, CT
2010 - 2014

I developed image analysis tools for fluorescent cell microscopy and gained expertise in microscopy experiments along the way. This entailed developing robust methods for determining cell orientation, segmenting cellular structures, and quantifying ratios of fluorescence signals. My analysis was largely used in determining the relationship between mechanical forces (e.g. stretching and fluid shear stress) and cellular biochemical responses, otherwise known as mechanotransduction. Mechanostransduction is important in stem cell differentiation, cancer metastasis, and cardiovascular diseases

BS in Physics
University of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA
2006 - 2010

I worked on a theoretical photon entanglement scheme for quantum information applications at the University of Cambridge. For my second major in Engineering Science, I developed a program for segmenting cell microscopy images as part of a project for quantifying molecular tension.
